quiz.title: Unit 4: Forces (Quiz 3)
quiz.subtitle: Comprehensive Forces Review and Applications (50 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Advanced Force Problems and Multi-Concept Applications

questions.question: A person stands on a scale in an elevator. When will the scale read less than their actual weight?
options: When the elevator moves at constant speed
questions.explanation: Downward acceleration reduces the normal force, making the scale read less.

questions.question: Which of the following is a contact force?
questions.explanation: Friction requires physical contact between surfaces, making it a contact force.

questions.question: A 5 kg box is pushed with 30 N on a surface with μₖ = 0.4. What is its acceleration?
Which free-body diagram shows a car moving right at constant speed?
options: Large arrow right, small arrow left
questions.explanation: Constant speed means zero net force - engine force right equals friction/air resistance left.

questions.question: A 60 kg person on a scale in an accelerating elevator reads 720 N. What is the elevator's acceleration?
What is the net force on a 2 kg object accelerating at 3 m/s² while experiencing 8 N of friction?
questions.explanation: F_net = ma = 2 × 3 = 6 N. But this is net after friction. Applied force = net + friction = 6 + 8 = 14 N.

questions.question: A rocket of mass 1000 kg expels gas at 500 m/s with 200 kg/s. What is thrust?
questions.explanation: Thrust = (dm/dt) × v = 200 kg/s × 500 m/s = 100,000 N.

questions.question: Why do action-reaction forces not cancel?
options: They are in the same direction
questions.explanation: Action-reaction pairs act on different objects, so they don't cancel for either object.

questions.question: A 10 kg block on a 30° incline has μₛ = 0.6. Will it slide?
questions.explanation: mg sin30° = 10×9.8×0.5 = 49 N down incline. Max static friction = μₛmg cos30° = 0.6×98×0.866 = 51 N. Friction > component, so no slide.

questions.question: What is the reaction force to a ball hitting a wall?
questions.explanation: The wall pushes back on the ball with equal force (Newton's Third Law).

questions.question: A car rounds a curve at constant speed. Why is it accelerating?
questions.explanation: Changing direction requires centripetal acceleration, even at constant speed.

questions.question: Two boxes (5 kg and 10 kg) are pushed with 45 N. What force does the 5 kg box exert on the 10 kg box?
questions.explanation: Total mass = 15 kg, a = 45/15 = 3 m/s². Force on 10 kg box = 10 × 3 = 30 N.

questions.question: Why does oil reduce friction?
questions.explanation: Lubricants create a smooth fluid layer that separates surfaces, reducing direct contact.

questions.question: A 500 N crate requires 250 N to start moving. What is μₛ?
questions.explanation: μₛ = fₛ_max/N = 250 N / 500 N = 0.5

questions.question: What is terminal velocity?
options: Speed when air resistance equals weight
questions.explanation: Terminal velocity occurs when upward air resistance equals downward weight.

questions.question: A 2 kg object has weight 19.6 N on Earth. On the Moon, what is its mass?
questions.explanation: Mass is amount of matter and doesn't change with location.

questions.question: Why do rockets work in space?
options: Newton's Third Law works in vacuum
questions.explanation: Expelling mass creates reaction force regardless of atmosphere (Newton's Third Law).

questions.question: A 1000 kg car accelerates from 0 to 27 m/s in 9 seconds. What average power is needed?
What force allows walking?
questions.explanation: Foot pushes ground backward, ground pushes foot forward (action-reaction).

questions.question: A 50 kg box is pulled with 200 N at 37° above horizontal (μₖ = 0.3). What is acceleration?
Why do falling leaves flutter?
questions.explanation: Changing orientation causes varying air resistance forces.

questions.question: A 1500 kg car brakes from 25 m/s to 0 in 5 seconds. What is the braking force?
What is the normal force on a 20 kg object on a 45° incline?
Why do cars have tread patterns?
questions.explanation: Treads channel water to maintain tire-road contact on wet surfaces.

questions.question: A 80 kg person in freefall reaches terminal velocity at 55 m/s. What is air resistance?
questions.explanation: At terminal velocity, air resistance equals weight = 80×9.8 = 784 N.

questions.question: Two teams tug-of-war, each pulling with 500 N. What is rope tension?
questions.explanation: The rope experiences 500 N tension throughout (teams pull equally in opposite directions).

questions.question: What happens to pressure when standing on one foot vs two?
questions.explanation: Same force over half the area doubles the pressure.

questions.question: A 0.1 kg arrow is shot with 100 N force for 0.05 seconds. What is its speed?
questions.explanation: Impulse = F×t = 100×0.05 = 5 N·s. Δv = impulse/m = 5/0.1 = 50 m/s.

questions.question: Why is static friction greater than kinetic?
questions.explanation: Stationary surfaces have time to form microscopic bonds that must be broken to start motion.

questions.question: A 5000 kg rocket has thrust 60,000 N. What is its initial acceleration?
What is the friction direction on braking tires?
questions.explanation: For braking, friction opposes motion - backward on tires.

questions.question: A 2 kg and 4 kg box are connected by string. 10 N pulls the 2 kg box. What is string tension?
questions.explanation: Total mass = 6 kg, a = 10/6 = 1.667 m/s². Tension on 4 kg = 4×1.667 = 6.67 N.

questions.question: Why do wet roads have less friction?
questions.explanation: Water reduces friction coefficient by lubricating the surface contact.

questions.question: A 60 kg skydiver with 0.7 m² cross-section reaches 53 m/s terminal velocity. What is drag force?
questions.explanation: At terminal velocity, drag equals weight = 60×9.8 = 588 N.

questions.question: What is the net force on an object moving at constant velocity in a circle?
questions.explanation: Circular motion requires centripetal (center-seeking) net force.

questions.question: A 100 kg object is lifted with acceleration 2 m/s². What is cable tension?
Why do rockets have stages?
questions.explanation: Dropping empty stages reduces mass, increasing acceleration.

questions.question: A 0.5 kg ball hits wall at 10 m/s and rebounds at 8 m/s in 0.1 s. What average force?
What is the reaction to a book pressing down on a table?
questions.explanation: Table pushes up on book with equal normal force.

questions.question: A 1500 kg car takes 8 seconds to go 0-100 km/h (27.8 m/s). What average power?
Why does mass affect terminal velocity?
options: More mass means more air resistance needed
questions.explanation: Heavier objects need more air resistance to balance their greater weight.

questions.question: A 10 kg block slides down 30° incline with μₖ = 0.2. What is acceleration?
What is the purpose of free-body diagrams?
questions.explanation: Free-body diagrams show all forces acting on a single object.

questions.question: A 70 kg person in elevator reads 630 N. What is elevator doing?
questions.explanation: Weight = 686 N, scale reads less, so accelerating down. N = m(g-a) → 630 = 70(9.8-a) → a = 0.8 m/s² down.

questions.question: Why can tiny thrusters maneuver large spacecraft?
questions.explanation: Even small forces produce acceleration in frictionless space (F=ma).

questions.question: A 0.2 kg ball thrown at 25 m/s is caught in 0.04 s. What average force on catcher?
What is the normal force direction?
questions.explanation: Normal force is always perpendicular (normal) to the surface.

questions.question: A 800 kg car needs 40 m to stop from 20 m/s. What is friction force?
Why do brakes work better on dry roads?
questions.explanation: Dry conditions maintain high friction coefficient between tires and road.

questions.question: A 5 kg and 3 kg mass hang on pulley. What is system acceleration?
What is the reaction to Earth's gravity on a person?
questions.explanation: Person pulls Earth upward with equal gravitational force.

scoreMessages.90: Outstanding! You've mastered complex force applications and multi-concept problems.
scoreMessages.70: Excellent work! You understand advanced concepts but should review multi-force systems.
scoreMessages.50: Good foundation! Focus on practicing inclined planes and connected systems.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Review Newton's Laws and work through multi-step problems systematically.
